headline: Good one
pros: It was really good and comfy.
cons: the food wasn´t that great.

headline: Great place to Work
pros: Great work environment and highly diverse
cons: long hours like many other financial institutions

headline: Trainee
pros: Great learning tools and resources
cons: Not a very collaborative workplace

headline: Client Service
pros: Work Hours, Flexibility, Great teammates
cons: 401k Match not full vested

headline: Great place
pros: Great place to work in
cons: Too much work to do

headline: Employee
pros: Fair pay, good benefits and good people... mostly.
cons: The loss of company morale in the last few years is unfortunate.  I really don't know many employees who are happy there.

headline: Janus is going through a lot of changes
pros: Good people, location and work/life balance
cons: Merger with Henderson has been messy. Lots of jobs cut or not replaced

headline: Trade Ops
pros: Great work environment, decent compensation
cons: I can not think of any cons

headline: Great Place to work
pros: Work/Life Balance, PTO, Health Ins.
cons: The usual corp. stuff, lots of buddy buddy system

headline: Here for a good time, not for a long time
pros: Great culture, top notch benefits,  management does their best to best to have your back, and prefer to promote from within
cons: Typical chain of command management system, who you know > what you know

headline: Competitive with no expertise
pros: Just glad I got an office
cons: I was on a small marketing that ended up being full of nasty, new employees who were all competitive for no reason. The management critiqued work on criteria they kept changing. The whole time I was there was a frustrating experience.  Also, my contractor colleagues often told me they were paid extremely late

headline: Senior Hr and Payroll Systems Analyst
pros:
Great company and good employee perks 
Flexibility 
Close interaction with Top management possible
cons:
Growth is very slow. 
Small team/single team member handling multiple business clients

headline: secretary
pros: flexibility/nice environment/open concept / open space / new office
cons: in balance of work load

headline: Intern
pros: Great Experience, Knowledgeable mentors, Experienced employees
cons: Sometimes there wasn't enough work to do.

headline: Not Very Challenging - Large Corp
pros: Well recognized company that everyone will know
cons: Not much room to challenge yourself if you are in the wrong dept.

headline: Desk Manager
pros: culture - intelligence - transparent - challenging - fun
cons: passive pressure - trending environment - been caught at a hurdle - difficult to see future

headline: Financial Analyst
pros: salary, benefits, work/life balance, people
cons: lack of fair management, after merger it getting worse

headline: Portfolio Manager
pros: Entrepreneurial and open culture, with little top down interference.
cons: Fund managers often the last to hear about Distribution's plans/thinking.

headline: Data Architect
pros: good work life balance. Good location.
cons: lot of politics. IT management is not knowledgable

headline: Not like it used to be
pros: Salary, benefits, mobility, employee perks
cons: Favoritism, advancement, long hours, communication

headline: Good company little career progression
pros: good pay and bonuses compared to other companies
cons: low amount of career progression

headline: HR Coordinator
pros: The management in my area are great.
cons: Location can sometimes be tricky.

headline: Financial Reporting Senior
pros:
Flexible
Fun
Busy Work
Friendly
Development
Some resources are provided when asked for
cons: Poor Leadership in the department, A LOT of over time

headline: Trade Operations
pros: *Work life balance, genuine people, awesome benefits - honestly the best company I have ever worked for in a corporate environment, departments actually work cohesively to  quickly problem solve.
cons: *Politics - but this is really at any company. My advice is to build relationships with people in upper level management quickly. New investment positions don't open up often.

headline: Entry Level Job
pros: Greats benefits (PTO, 401K), No weekends and always done by 4 PM M-F.
cons: Some of the procedures in place are overboard making it difficult to communicate with investors, a lot of changes in management in the last few months, communication within the company isn't always clear,  High employee turnover

headline: Overall Great Place to Work
pros: Great people that work there, nice Cherry Creek location, good pay, benefits
cons: Not real innovative, hard to change things in technology because of size, not many opportunities to move up in technology

headline: Operations Analyst
pros: Great people, nice benefits.  Enjoyed the company - at times the employees did not buy into the leaderships vision.
cons: leadership's vision seems to change a lot.

headline: QUALITY ASSURANCE ANALYST
pros: GOOD LIFE BALANCE and benefits
cons: Not holding on to good employees when needed.

headline: good company did not like management
pros: work is easy. management is not
cons: did not like management or work

headline: Client Relations Analyst
pros: Decent workload, great people to work with
cons: Cubicle farm, complete 9-5 job

headline: Sales
pros: Good products, people and benefits
cons: Not looking to hire from within.

headline: Very positive experience
pros: Worked with some of the smartest people in the industry. Learned a lot. Gold star benefits. Nice perks, awesome coworkers.
cons: Opportunity to grow and learn was limited by the team and personalities you are assigned and their willingness to mentor.

headline: Manager
pros: Great culture, allowed to do your job, high expectations
cons: Can't mail it in here

headline: Uncertain Times
pros: vacation time a plus, allowed to take long lunches. Given a staff that does all the work
cons: Too many high level opinions on how to run a company. Will not take advice from leaders like me.

headline: Review
pros:
Friendly atmosphere
Good Culture
Nice Management
Good location
cons:
Lack of room for growth
Salary
Bonus

headline: Fun company, but lots of politics
pros: Great culture, lots of fun events thrown for employees, amazing holiday party, and great benefits.  Most people are great to work with (depending on the department).
cons: Very political atmosphere, and it's very hard to get promoted. I've seen people who have been in their roles for 10 years before getting promoted. It's very dependent on whether you have a supportive boss who will develop you to progress in your career.

headline: Changing Culture, Less Colorado, More Boston/New York
pros: Excellent benefits, great location in Cherry Creek, and an amazing and interesting history.
cons:
Janus used to be a very unique and special place, due in large part to the values and culture directly brought into being by its original founder.  The company used to be, proudly, Colorado culture and quite specifically not a typical Wall Street company. 
 Eventually, after Tom Bailey's retirement, the executive leadership became more and more East Coast financial slickers, which over time undermined the 4-decade long unique culture that was.

headline: Total chaos
pros: Generally the people are really nice and great to work with.  Home office in Denver is a plus and they have great employee benefits.  A lot of smart people that work really hard but we don't get the desired results.
cons: Too much turnover and layoffs are coming with the upcoming Henderson merger.  No matter how hard we try it's difficult to get any traction for moving the dial on AUM and sales.  AUM has been generally flat for what seems like the past decade.

headline: Most amazing place I've ever worked.
pros: People, Culture, Opportunity, Benefits, Fun, Innovative, Energizing atmosphere, you are surrounded by smart/hard working people that become life long friends
cons: None. I can't think of any. It's truly a wonderful place. Anyone would be lucky to work here. No complaints.

headline: investment accountant
pros: benefits nice people lots of free food!
cons: toxic culture, people are promoted based on who they are buddies with, good people will eventuaally leave like i did!

headline: Vacation and Paid Time Off
pros: Generous PTO package as your years of service and level increases. You will find you have more than you ever could need. Employees can also roll a certain amount of PTO to the next year.
cons: Rollover PTO must be used within the first 6 months of the new year or you lose it.

headline: Happy but...
pros:
- Great Benefits
- Great Diversity Initiatives and Professional Development 
- You can tell the EC really cares about the employees
- The people
- Work / life balance
cons:
- There is constant change happening there. From PM turnover, to mergers, to restructuring. We would always joke "never a dull moment" which is an unsettling feeling to employees.
- Sales / Marketing misalignment
- The "new" CMO is from the old school thought of marketing
-  Constant random acts of marketing and no real research of what is performing well and what isn't. Employees create so much collateral that doesn't even get utilized. Not for lack of effort, but the market has changed. 92% of content in general doesn't ever get used. This is not an efficient use of the marketing folks time. They would really benefit from more BI and more modern approaches to marketing.
- A limited amount of people make the decisions and if you don't abide by their way of doing things, then you are ousted. 
-

headline: Janus Day Care
pros: Great managers, fun environment, company events and happy hours are never skimped on.
cons: You are expected to go above and beyond for your partner, who generally is some tenured white man who treats you poorly that doesn't know how to use an ipad, its fine if you want a steady job and pay and don't mind being treated as an inferior member of the "team".

headline: Supervisor
pros:
Worked with a smart group of people. 
Cooperative and supportive environment. 
Change and learning highly encouraged.
Best work experience I have had.
cons:
IT restrictions causing inefficiencies. 
Tendency to say 'yes' to everything before operationally ready. Yes we can trade this. Yes we can provide the client anything they ask for.

headline: Product Specialist
pros:
Janus is a great place to start a career in finance. The employees are good people that genuinely care about one another. 
The company puts on a lot of activities to build team moral.
cons: I don't have anything bad to say about Janus.

headline: The Armpit of Equity Analysis
pros: Biggest investment shop in Denver.  The nicest pro I can give is that there is free soda.
cons:
Janus may seem impressive on a resume but the organization is completely dysfunctional.  New senior analysts are hired based on business school pedigree, or more importantly, ability to effectively gossip and socialize within the office.  Promotions never materialize because experience/hard work doesn't matter here.   The investment team consists of ideologues whom struggle making active investing decisions which is pretty evident when looking at historical returns.  I have never worked for a company with lower morale.  At least in equity research, the best way to gauge whether management is lying to you is when they open their mouths.  The ongoing merger was formed to benefit top executives while bonuses declined and no raises were given to most employees.  Many people join Janus to live in Denver and I would caution against this.  Management will lure you in only to trap you in a city with limited competition.  Please exhaust other options before accepting a position with Janus.  It is impossible to break through the bureaucracy of this organization.

Women and minorities need not apply here.  Most women have left due to the non-welcoming environment and there are no minorities.  The only viewpoint here is one of a white, Ivy League male with a stay at home wife and country club membership.   I am shocked there hasn’t been a lawsuit yet.

headline: Soul sucking
pros: Team members were all seemingly cool people.
cons: Sucked into a job through a staffing agency, paid well below the amount of work you were putting in. Had no drive, and no incentive to do better than an extremely average job every day.

headline: Associate
pros: Very laid back environment for a financial firm. Lots of great people work here. It is not unusual to leave the building for a coffee and meet half the firm doing the same thing. It is easy to have a work/life balance.
cons: Being "social" is far more important than being knowledgeable and hard-working. It can be very hard getting things done as there is not a sense of urgency and a lack of professionalism by employees at all levels of the firm. It may seem great that you can grab a coffee or get lunch whenever you want, but after awhile the lack of structure and lack of passion/drive gets on your nerves.

headline: traditional firm
pros: good benefit, good place for retirement
cons: no growth inside, need build international development plan

headline: Great Investment Management Company. Not so good people
pros: The work you perform is very rewarding, it has sound and immediate impact to the company's overall objective and mission. People are friendly and willing to go out of their way to help you. Great software tools they are using for their trading. You are surrounded by people always pushing the status quo and going above of beyond, not settling for the simple answer and analyzing more than necessary.
cons: Management isn't always forward thinking. Very bureaucratic. Can be extremely political, you do have to kiss butt to the right people to move up the ladder, which is extremely slow. In the headquarters, in North Cherry Creek, the culture and climate is good but people do act like their poop doesn't stink. This is also noticeable in the company holiday party and summer socials/ happy hours. Compensation lags a bit behind what other competitors pay for the same position in the Denver metro area. Cublics are on every floor, which is extremely outdated, with the size of their AUM you would think they can get better desks for the lowest level employees. There is also no kitchen in the headquarters to eat/ mingle during lunch hours.

headline: Great place
pros: Friendly, challenging, results driven, meritorious, forward-looking, socially progressive working environment full of exceptionally smart professionals.
cons: The building lacks a cafeteria, or any place to gather socially or to brain sort mans the interior decor is very dated and depressing, and conducive to creating silos by cutting you off from colleagues.

headline: Solid company, good management practices
pros: The company had a good HR department, that helped managers and supervisors provide appropriate leadership and feedback
cons: The company sometimes went through times of turmoil, with top leadership and PM changes. The changes affected the external reputation of the company more than directly impacting employee tasks.

headline: Great benefits, awesome culture
pros:
generous PTO
+1 to company events :)
cons:
Lack of growth
Job can get repetitive

headline: Good place to work
pros: People you work with are great! They train you for 2 weeks before putting you to work with real customers. Paid training with a raise once you've completed it.
cons: Supervisors always seemed to be changing

headline: Too many cooks in the kitchen
pros: Great PTO and benefits.  Some very forward thinking and smart people at the grassroots level of the organization.  CEO has done a great job leading the organization.
cons: Lots of internal politics and self preservation concerns to deal with at Director level and above.  The organization would be better off if teams worked better together and were interested in what's best for Janus and not what's best for their year end review.

headline: This company is very behind on the times.
pros: Fellow employees are friendly and intelligent. There isn't much else positive here honestly. Free soda and water. And good location.
cons: Archaic policies, worthless upper management/middle management, rampant favoritism. Most the Janus funds are garbage and they lose 5 to 6 percent of their direct customers each month.

headline: Awesome company--poor returns by Fund Managers
pros: Excellent training and preparation for Series 6 and 63 exams. Well run organization that seemed to genuinely care about its employees. Great way to gain knowledge of the industry.
cons: Not much room to move up if you are starting at the bottom (customer service rep). Fund Managers have incredibly poor investment returns, which doesn't do much for retaining or getting new customers.

headline: JANUS Employee
pros: This is a great company to work for.  I have been very pleased with every aspect.m I could not be happier.
cons: There is nothing negative that I would say about this company.  Everything has been really great. I could not be happier.

headline: Sales Desk Manager
pros: Great place to be, healthy work life balance.
cons: Nothing I can really think of...everything is good.

headline: Generally a good place to work
pros: great benefits, good people, great location
cons: lack of communication, opaque processes of how to get help from management/HR if necessary.

headline: Janus Institutional Ops
pros: Great Company to work for
cons: It's work, like any place

headline: Good people, no room for growth
pros: Great benefits, PTO and health insurance
cons: no profit sharing plan available, bonuses aren't great

headline: Management
pros: People, Challenging, Good growth prospects
cons: Too thinly staffed at most levels

headline: Analyst
pros: Good work place,good work experience
cons: i company  does not  treat  contractors  very well.

headline: Good for 1-2yrs just to have on your resume
pros: Benefits were good and included ESOP, health and dental insurance from day 1.  Decent compensation.
cons: Poor communication from senior management leaves you wondering what the future will bring.  Culture change over the last five-ten years with new senior management rotating in and out has been dramatic and negative. Although compensation was good, there were inequalities between individuals doing similar work that could be dramatic and creates bitterness and lack of cohesion.

headline: Sr Business Analyst
pros: People, Financial Services in Denver
cons: Leadership churn at the top

headline: Portfolio Accountant
pros: Compared to many companies in Denver, this one is quite good. Onboarding and training is solid and comprehensive so new employees can catch up fast. Coworkers are great and are always willing to help. There are opportunities for advancement if you work hard (and smart). IT department is quite good and is able to resolve all issues within couple of hours.
cons:
It can be slow sometimes.
Contractors can be treated better.
Relatively high turnover. 
Quite a lot of office politics and gossip.

headline: Too much can be too much.
pros: I worked at Janus when they had offices in Austin, TX.  The employees were great, the salary was competitive, and we were provided free lunches (this was due to the long hours we were forced to work).
cons: Too much MANDATORY overtime.  When I was hired, I was told that I would have to work overtime from time to time, what happened instead was I had to work MANDATORY overtime EVERYDAY!

headline: Place a joke
pros: They overpay for average performance
cons: Political times a million.  People running the show now have never been in sales.  Place a joke

headline: It's a mix
pros: The mid- and lower-level people are generally good to work with.  Pay is reasonable and benefits are good.  Work is fast paced and challenging.
cons: Higher level management are very political and do not tend to listen to mid-level.  High level decisions are not always well thought through before throwing a project at people, which in the end does not get done and wastes a lot of time and effort.

headline: If you want to downgrade, take a job w/ this firm
pros: There is nothing good to be said...
cons:
Corrupt dirty politicians...that is what this firm reminds me of.  Middle management is useless (they don't care for the overall benefit to the firm's success, nor their team's success.  They only self promote).  Senior management goes through a revolving door.  No accountability, the firm as a whole is unethical, unprofessional and inefficient.  This firm lacks leadership and good values.  You can tell anyone to do a job, but can you inspire them to do their job? 
I would not recommend anyone to work for them nor invest in them.

headline: Janus Intern
pros: Good team. Great work environment.
cons: Difficult to land a job after school

headline: Senior Manager
pros: Pay is highly competitive.  Benefits are excellent.  Smart people are looking out for the investor.  Approach to find the right investments is sound.
cons: Very political environment.  Highly competitive and this can make some people behave in ways that are not a company I wanted to continue with.

headline: great people and culture
pros: Great work culture, friendly co-workers, accessibility of managers. Also, Denver is a great place to be!
cons: A little bit unstructured; no formal training system in place for interns (at least was the case for me).

headline: Manager
pros: There are many great and passionate people who work at Janus and who are committed to providing the best for their clients.
cons: Top management says they care about employees and improving employee engagement but their actions and words speak more of "If you don't like it, leave" attitude. The organization continues to struggle financially. There is a lack of flexibility and attention to the differences in generational preferences by top management.

headline: Operations
pros: Great culture. Fair pay. Outstanding benefits package.
cons: None that I can recall.

headline: Wholesaler
pros: Good compensation, plan. Manageable territories. Good teamwork among peers. Good benefits and easy to use employee benefits website.
cons: Management was inexperience with the business they were managing. Had to defend performance a lot. This was due to the woeful performance post 2000 and choppy/not very well conveyed performance post 2008.

headline: Still a good employer
pros: Janus is remains a good place to work. Pros include benefit costs, 401k match, bonus plan, time off, work from home options, nice location
cons: Pay is less than the local market is paying

headline: Senior Service Specialist
pros: Great people to work with.
cons: Most positions are severely underpaid.

headline: Pay not competitive with Industry
pros: Great great benefits! Awesome people. The company really has a lot to offer in terms of quality of life, but the pay is not great.
cons: The pay is not keeping up with the cost of living in Denver or the industry. Many people are leaving to go to competitors because of that.

headline: Loving it
pros: Great place to work and great people
cons: You could get really busy but that could be a good thing

headline: Life at janus
pros: Great benefits compared to almost any company, good pay on a relative basis for most positions. great location to work in.
cons: Very political within the marketing department and between departments, work-life balance  leaves a little to be desired for some positions.

headline: Chaos
pros: People were awesome generally and its located in Denver CO
cons: Constant changes in leadership.  I have never seen a company with this much change and big highs and big lows all at once.  A lot of turnover and inflows have been a huge challenge for many years and seems to still be a challenge

headline: Never-ending change
pros: Great city, company location.  Compensation high for the area.
cons: Company has become Pimco of the Rockies. Chances to take advantage of positive market over recent years were squandered.

headline: I love this company!
pros: Janus was a wonderful place to work. For me, it was a wonderful work life balance and I enjoyed going to work because of the people I was surrounded by.
cons: I can't think of many cons. For the most part I enjoyed it and would be happy to work there again.

headline: Institutional
pros: Janus Capital Group offered great benefits and salaries. I worked with fantastic, dedicated colleagues in Denver, CO.  The company was active in the community.
cons: Janus Capital Group tended to promote dead-weight managers from within and overload the subordinate employees.  Typical 80/20 rule scenario where 20% of the people contributed 80% of work.  Higher salaries and good benefits trapped employees in some awful positions.

headline: Sr. Systems Analyst
pros:
Excellent support with effective tools and infrastructure

Outstanding benefits

Healthy atmosphere - high levels of collaboration

Great, competitive pay
cons: Investment professionals enjoy a lot of power and sway

headline: Associate
pros: Good Benefit, health work and life balance
cons: Slow promotion, not making a goof effort of keeping talents

headline: janus capital
pros: Smart people, room for advancement, Great work life balance
cons: Great company, really no major cons None

headline: Director
pros: Great people; great location; competitive benefits; company performance is improving with positive net flows, investment performance and stock returns.
cons: Accelerated employee turnover of top talent and poorly executed new product innovation strategy.

headline: Information Technology - Run the other way
pros: Decent pay but no work life balance.
cons: Technology  department is probably the worst I have ever worked at.  I could list all the reasons but why bother when nothing will change.

headline: goodlearningexperience
pros: good work conditions in the company
cons: far off from home place

headline: Politics, politics, politics
pros: Great people at the VP level and below.  God work life balance
cons: Senior executives seem to think if they surround themselves with smart people that do not do anything that the company will prosper.  Very heavy politics and those who name up will do well irrespective of results.

headline: Seems to be getting better.
pros: Janus has great benefits.  I like the culture and how everyone is friendly and inviting.  There is room for advancement and they have programs that allow you to shadow or intern in different departments.
cons: There are a lot of politics and if you aren't in the "in-crowd" it's harder to get to a new or higher position.  It's hard to get recognized for things you go above and beyond for.

headline: Great benefits, friendly employees and CEO
pros: People are great and so is the management
cons: Not an industry leader which can be hard competing with other firms

headline: Good Company - but...
pros: They try to promote good company culture, have good people around as well.
cons: Senior Management looks down upon employees, their actions don't match their words.

headline: Janus Capital experience
pros: Great place to learn about investments. Very generous benefits and time off.
cons: Little room for growth in a technical direction when you reach the title as Senior xxxx

headline: Chaotic
pros: Nice people...you can make decent money in sales or very little. Feast or famine...luck of the draw. Free soda machine!
cons: Middle management is lost...constantly changing comp plans. Some very 'dated' sales managers in their techniques...showing up @ 10 AM and cashing a fat paycheck. Management doesn't follow through on ideas and are poor @ communication. Employees promoted strictly on quantitative measures. Doesn't matter how much you help your colleagues or how many great ideas you come up with. Good old boy club.

headline: Sales desk
pros: the sales desk at galleria is a great place to get industry experience.  Now that the firm hired the bond king from Pimco, they stand a chance of stopping the bleeding of assets that has taken place for over 5 years now.
cons: If you hate corporate politics and playing the game, then stay away from being an ISC.  the compensation is tilted towards a select few on the desk and you will struggle to make more than 60k in your territory. Management will tell you the average is 80K but keep in mind the 5 employees at the top making 130k are driving that average up making it look higher

headline: Solid company
pros: great benefits, good location (Denver and Cherry Creek North) overall but could be long commute unless you live close to downtown, there are many good hearted people who work at Janus.
cons: poor work life balance, difficult to attain resources (additional head count, office supplies, system maintenance, business travel), internal political structure can be challenging (don't upset the wrong person or you may find yourself unemployed), different management styles not encouraged (prefer leading by intimidation at times)

headline: Bad Experience in the TA
pros: The People. Your coworkers are the only thing that make the job doable.
cons: Non-existent work life balance. 1/3 of the year blacked out for time off. Require constant overtime and don't allow staff time off to handle things as small as doctor appointments or significant life events. Extreme micromanagement which is done very rudely.

headline: Well past it's glory days.
pros: Ofiices are in Cherry Creek with many amenities.  Company has many perks for those it likes.
cons: Toxic culture running a business in decline dependent on a steady stream of new investment cattle.  All products offered thru wrap accounts with the hope that investors signup without their due diligence. Management team is lining their pockets as long as this gravy train will allow.  Assets walking out the door all the time.

headline: Clueless and Visionless IT (Extreme Lack) of Leadership - Primitive approcah towards the data needs of the business.
pros:
Amazing non-managerial people to work with. 
Great benefits
Cherry Creek is a desirable neighborhood to work in.
cons:
At Janus, during my time I saw senior resources leaving because of incompetent managers within a year. I noticed people being promoted not due to their talent but other reasons.
Extreme Internal Politics

headline: Only OK.
pros: I met some really great people during my tenure at Janus, and many of them are still there.  The benefits were good, pay was fair, and roof deck parties with a view of the Rocky Mountains were always fun.  Cherry Creek North is an awesome location.
cons: Shared resources among three different investment management firms is a challenging structure.  The cultures have not melded together.  The hierarchy and many layers of managers make it difficult to be heard, get answers, and move the needle.

headline: Company is Failing
pros: Insurance, free parking, mall is across the street
cons:
Always a high turnover rate of employees in operations and technology
Back office staff are not compensated fairly
Marketing department is ineffective
Information technology managers and staff are highly incompetent

The overall company outlook is not bright: It is no secret that Janus makes revenue by charging exorbitant fees to their clients to  hold onto their money and not by their fund performance.  Janus funds are consistently low in performance.  There is always some "buzz" created in the news about Janus some fund or dividend having a marginal uptick, but historically Janus outflows mean a "neutral", "hold", or "sell" rating.

headline: Ever changing managment
pros: Very smart people who work hard and play hard.  The company is very client focused and compliance oriented.  Strong ethical standards in the investment department and in the rank and file.  If you do not find change stimulating, this isn't your best place to work
cons: If you are not in the investment department, salaries are no longer competitive even within the Denver metro area.  Great training ground but constantly losing top performers to competitors.  .

headline: Accoutant
pros: Great company culture,  pay is very competitive with the industry, and office is in a great Denver location.  Very pleased.
cons: Work can be very repetitive.  Company is in a turn around stage so budget was cut and its hard to tell what the future holds.

headline: Constant change
pros: Highly motivated and friendly work environment. Location could be the best in the country for asset manager.   Lot of employees very active in charity.   A lot of opportunities to grow and move among different areas of the company.
cons: Highest management positions currently filled by outsiders. Company searching for place in a market that has changed a lot since company's massive success years ago.   IT always a challenge to keep up with innovation but management making changes for the positive.

headline: A company in secular decline
pros: Great location, solid benefits, talented workforce.
cons: The elephant in the room is that actively managed mutual funds are dying a slow death, and Janus mutual funds in aggregate are average at best. 4-5 years of outflows have permeated into company culture. The sales and marketing organizations are in constant turnover trying to put lipstick on a pig - and senior management is too busy worried about poor investment performance to manage any other areas of the business effectively. The company is dying very very slowly.

headline: This company truly lives up to the two-faced mythology
pros:
Good Location.
Pays well but is it worth your sanity?
cons:
Favoritism is rampant and expectations of individuals are not uniform or consistent. 
Politics in this place is as toxic as it can get.
There is no adequate training for new employees. They expect you to figure it all out on your own.
There is a culture of gossip, fear and intimidation embraced and perpetuated by management. 
Diversity is virtually non-existent and many of these people will treat you as if you were just another transaction. 
You will not get feedback on your performance. Instead, they will talk behind your back and make you an outcast.
Lots of incompetent project managers who have no clue how things work but love to throw buzz words around. Stop it please! 
This isn't a place that allows creatives to thrive.

Other things you might want to be aware of:
*If you are slow to pick things up, you will be a target.
*If you have any sort of ambition, you will lose it.
*If you want managers who care about your success, you will be disappointed.
*If you think you will be respected here, you will not.
*If you aren't a yes man (or woman), you will struggle.
*If you want to express an opinion, you will quickly find it doesn't matter.
*If you show respect, you will not be shown it back.
*If you give your two weeks, you will not see a quiet exit.

headline: Depends on what side of the business you work in
pros: If you work on the investment side of the business, the pay and benefits are outstanding.
cons: If you work in a supporting role, such as the transfer agency, call center, back office, there is very little appreciation or value placed on what you do.

headline: Interesting company with great benefits, but seriously disconnected IT Management
pros: The environment is upbeat and modern, benefits are second to none. Multiple locations to choose from, not just Cherry Creek. Interesting variety of work.
cons: New IT management from Boston were so out of touch, it defies logic. So many long timers left or were forced out, that I can only assume that was the plan, in order to cut costs.

headline: Great place to build your career and skillset
pros: friendly collaborative culture working with talented driven indivudals
cons: You can get caught up in the politics if you don't pay attention.

headline: There's been good and there's been bad.
pros: The company offers good health insurance benefits.
cons: Favoritism is rampant and expectations of individuals are not uniform or consistent.  There's a culture of gossip--which is also embraced and perpetuated by management.

headline: not equal for women
pros: best fit for single's who don't want a life.
cons: Don't respect older women in IT.

headline: Great benefits, nice coworkers, but not so great management
pros: Benefits, time-off, great people, great location
cons: Horrible leadership, condescending, untrusting, abusive  managers

headline: Quantitative Trader
pros: Open and Free culture, people are very helpful
cons: Long working hours just like other financial services institutions

headline: Great place to work
pros: Really good team to work with - very dedicated group.  Main building in the heart of Cherry Creek - fun location.
cons: Like anyplace, can be political

headline: Fun, learned a ton.
pros: Diverse group of individuals. Perks were outstanding. The story of Janus, the background was ingrained in the call center group.
cons: Overtime can be great, but there comes a time when it becomes too much.

headline: Pretty good company to work for
pros: Great benefits, good location, salary is fair, nice extra employee perks i.e. holiday party, employee appreciation day in the summer, etc.
cons: Continually overhauling existing processes whether it's needed or not, too much "high level" thinking without realizing the impact on the day-to-day processes.  If it isn't broken, don't fix it!  It's expected that people are involved in or contribute to special projects as part of their job nowadays regardless of the level of competency or interest.

headline: Great company, with great culture!
pros: The culture is amazing.  Tom Bailey instilled a more relaxed atmosphere then most mutual fund companies even with his absence.  Information is freely shared about fund performance and management.
cons: Communication is key.  There were often changes that were not communicated until they occurred.  There are business reasons for this, however.

headline: Good company to work for
pros: Nice people, great benefits, flexible work schedule, great office location.
cons: Often times there is no obvious career path. Some departments can be very political.

headline: You're promoted by being a favorite not your hard work
pros: Great benefits and work life balance is as well.
cons: No raises for 3 years straight while other firms in the same industry are giving raises, 401k mutual funds only offers Janus mutual funds and no outside mutual funds, management tries to tell you things are getting better by buying you new office supplies, if you are hourly they will not pay yu for overtime

headline: Fun, young work place with lots of talent
pros:
- Smart People
- Solid work environment 
- Opportunity for advancement 
-Company cares about employees
cons:
-Politics can get in the way of good business
- Still a little gun shy from the late 90's
- Trying too hard to get 'talent' on the trade floor

headline: Good company to work for - but issues
pros: Benefits, location, culture, smart people
cons: Lack of growth opportunities, top heavy management, salary structure

headline: This once was a great company to work for.
pros:
- Good benefits package
- Nice location
- Decent training and development department
cons:
- Overpaid Managers and Directors and incompetency throughout the organization
 - Ineffective HR department
- Nepotism and Favoritism is extensive
- Lack of accountability at ALL levels
- Your opinions are only valued if they are in agreement with your department head
- You are rewarded and promoted based your networking (sucking up) skills, not your talent and ability to actually get things done.  
- Lack of any type of manager assistance or encouragement towards career development.

headline: not a good place to work
pros: - health insurance is decent but the out of pocket rx drug deductible is higher than other insurance plans
cons:
- lots of overtime
- high turn over rate
- overpaid middle managers and directors who do nothing
- useless hr department
- sick days are taken out of of your PTO
- most of the good people leave

headline: “This place drains the life out of you!”
pros:
*Exposure to the trading department of a mutual fund not in a major financial hub.
*Free lunch!
*Seeing the light of day during the winter and hitting the running trails early during summer.
*Gym in the building - although pretty small.
*Sweet benefits.
cons:
*If you are slow to pick things up, you will be a target.
*If you have any sort of ambition, you will lose it.
*If you want managers who care about your success, you will be disappointed.
*If you think you will be respected here, you will not.
*If you aren't a yes man (or woman), you will struggle.
*If you want to express an opinion, you will quickly find it doesn't matter.
*If you show respect, you will not be shown it back.
*if you make a mistake, you will be told it doesn't affect your future - it does!
*if you want to transfer departments, you will again realize nobody respects you.
*If you give your two weeks, you will not see a quiet exit.

headline: A top place to work
pros: Great people, great location in cherry creek, fantastic corporate culture, generous PTO and benefits.
cons: Nothing obvious I can think of.

headline: Great Place to work
pros: access to very smart Coworkers
cons: Tough to get promoted internally

headline: Great first job because you won't know any better.
pros:
- Nice location in Cherry Creek
- The benefits are similar to but not better than other financial services companies in Denver.
- If you like doing the same repetitive work every day and not being challenged mentally this is a good place to work.
- If you like the status quo, this is a great department.
cons:
- If you're not good at playing politics, this is not the department for you.  
- If you are a professional and know how to behave in an office, this is not the department for you. 
- If you like to have a work/life balance, this is not the department for you.
- If you expect your manager to help you develop and grow as an employee, this is not the department for you.
- If you expect the department to have the same rules for every employee, this is not the place for you.
- If you don't like to be micromanaged, this is not the place for you.
- If you think you may want to eventually get a promotion, this is not the place for you.  
- If you think management in the department should be transparent, this is not the place for you.
- If you would like to work for a department that has a good reputation and isn't viewed as romper room by the rest of the company, this is not the place for you.

headline: Exodus of talented people has left the weak in charge. Past time for a change!
pros:
-Good opportunity to get foot in the door
-Denver company pays outsized salaries, bonuses and benefits
-Capital markets are dynamic and interesting
cons:
-Current managers in the investment department are extremely weak
-Sucking up is rewarded, not a meritocracy
-Almost all the talented employees and managers have long flown the coop
-Results have been weak and likely to stay weak

headline: Used to be great - full of talented and energetic people...but that has changed.
pros: The pay is excellent and the location is superb.
cons: Exec. management has been turning over and the firm is mismanaged

headline: Great learning experience but politics are toxic
pros:
Great learning experience
Good pay and benefits
Denver is a great place to live
Work was challenging and intellectually stimulating
cons:
Politics were pervasive and toxic to the culture 
Minimal constructive actionable feedback from managers
Not a genuine meritocracy
Too hierarchical

headline: Janus Capital as  Company
pros: Hiring manager was extremely thorough and made me feel very comfortable during a usually stressful process. Six full weeks of extensive training. Managers were very fair and very approachable when I needed more information. Many employee perks that were not job related; company picnic, Holiday party, company anniversary events, paid sick days and personal days.
cons: The only con for this company was the commute, (40 miles each way.)

headline: You'll get paid well, but will it be worth it?
pros: Company provides good benefits, however not as good as they used to be.
cons:
Not efficient work environment. 
Often long work hours are expected, hard for many to get promoted.

headline: Up beat, aggressive firm
pros: Best company to work for, I've never had an employer strive to improve my abilities.
cons: Mainly only located in Denver

headline: Great history
pros: Wonderful people at most levels of the company
cons: Current leadership seems to be grasping at straws and has lost site of their brand.

headline: Great company to work for
pros: great benefits, opportunity to work with knowledgable individuals, will learn a lot
cons: often times long work hours are expected, hard for many to get promoted

headline: Company ni the middle of transformation
pros: A whole lot of smart people working here
cons:
Company's growth is in question 
Limited opportunities for advancement

headline: Good old boys club
pros:
-HQ is in Denver, CO
-Large mutual fund company
cons:
-Good old boys club
-Skill set, background, and strengths don't matter, it is all about the political game.
-Poor fund performance
-Lack of leadership
-Manage by intimidation
-Micro management at it's finest
-Little to no coaching
-Retention is an issue
-Zero room for movement within the organization

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great environment, casual dress, room for advancement.  Good location and seems to be well run with a youthful core team
cons: Not a lot of cross training available and lack of exposure to management.  pay could be better for amount of time put in

headline: Great co-workers, benefits, and pay
pros: Benefits, pay, co-workers, and location
cons: nepotism is rampant and sr directors and vps are either brilliant or buffoons.

headline: Not bad but IA was a poorly run department.
pros:
Awesome coworkers
Challenging work
Good work environment
The internal internship program was good but could have done more to do shorter term (week or month) internships to foster more cooperation.
cons:
Constantly looked down upon by other departments and senior mgmt
Company had previous incompetent mgmt
The better you were the more work you got and the more you had to pick up the slack of others
Salary and bonus weren't commensurate with the work you did

headline: Very nice group of people. Outdated technology reduces job efficiency.
pros: Great benefits compared to other companies in the industry. Very good communication from the portfolio managers and analysts on a regular basis to keep everyone informed about the products, disciplines and product challenges.
cons: Poor training that was virtually absent. New trainees were given a stack of information to read and told to basically figure things out. It felt like a sink or swim atmosphere, where the managers did not train the new hires. Expect compensation changes on a regular basis. Department was managed by fear and intimidation where employees were afraid to ask questions or voice concerns.

headline: Horrific
pros: Decent benefits. Can't say much else.
cons: Stay away from Trade Operations. Completely superficial environment and favortism galore. Management is completely incompetent unless you pucker up and lose face. After working there, completely sucked the life out of me since I refused to kiss butt.

headline: Best company I have ever experienced
pros:
- benefits package is outstanding. the best I have seen out of dozens of companies I consulted in the past
- people are fabulous in this company. energetic, helpful, play team. At least that's how I feel at IT and the business units I support. I think that covers a fair wide range of the company
- pay at IT is pretty good
cons: - you don't really have a whole lot of chances to move around in the company. they will rather hire from outside than transitioning an employee from one role to another with some training. These employees ended up getting let go or they will just quit eventually once they find their jobs are dead ends.

headline: Janus Manager
pros: Good benefits and salaries are typically in the top 20 percent of comparable firms. Pleasant people and fairly competent management.
cons: Communication from executive management to associate level can be inconsistent and the corporate grapevine is relied upon which is highly suspect at times. Management is very young and most of the senior managers that really understood the business have left the company.

headline: Janus Review
pros: The company is always trying to make itself better. The atmosphere is very competitive, which can be good or bad. If the company does well employees are rewarded and vice versa if the company does bad. The company tries to help employees become better leaders and professionals through classes they offer.
cons: There is a large disconnect between the investment team and operations. Competitiveness can lead to a feeling of unfair practices for instance even though I'm a great employee I don't get what I think I'm deserved.

headline: it's ok
pros: The people are very intelligent and tend to work well with others. I liked the amount of vacation time and sick time.
cons: The hours can be long, but that is to be expected when working on wall street, so I guess I can't complain too much!
